Szpiro’s small points conjecture for cyclic covers

Ariyan Javanpeykar and Rafael von Känel
Abstract

Let XXX be a smooth, projective and geometrically connected curve of genus at least two, defined over a number field. In 1984, Szpiro conjectured that XXX has a “small point”. In this paper we prove that if XXX is a cyclic cover of prime degree of the projective line, then XXX has infinitely many “small points”. In particular, we establish the first cases of Szpiro’s small points conjecture, including the genus two case and the hyperelliptic case. The proofs use Arakelov theory for arithmetic surfaces and the theory of logarithmic forms.

1 Introduction

Let XXX be a smooth, projective and geometrically connected curve of genus at least two, defined over a number field. In 1984, Szpiro [] conjectured that XXX has a “small point”, where a “small point” is an algebraic point of the curve XXX with “height” bounded from above in a certain way. We refer to Section 2 for a precise formulation of Szpiro’s small points conjecture. Szpiro proved that his conjecture implies an “effective Mordell conjecture”. In other words, Szpiro’s remarkable approach shows that to bound the height of all rational points of any curve XXX, it suffices to produce for any curve XXX at least one “small point”. The small points conjecture was studied in Szpiro’s influential seminars [], see also Szpiro’s articles [].

The results of this paper are as follows. Let 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} be the set of curves XXX as above which are cyclic covers of prime degree of the projective line. For example, if XXX has genus two or is hyperelliptic, then X∈𝒞X𝒞X\in\mathcal{C}. Our first result (see Theorem 3.1) gives that any X∈𝒞X𝒞X\in\mathcal{C} has infinitely many “small points”. In particular, we establish the first cases of Szpiro’s small points conjecture. Furthermore, we improve Theorem 3.1 for hyperelliptic curves (see Theorem 3.2) and for genus two curves (see Theorem 3.3) in the sense that we produce “smaller points” on such curves. To give the reader a more concrete idea of our results we now state a special case of Theorem 3.3. If the curve XXX has genus two and is defined over ℚℚ{\mathbb{Q}}, then XXX has infinitely many algebraic points xxx that satisfy

max(hN⁢T(x),h(x))≤(10∏p)106fragmentsfragmentsnormal-(subscripthNTfragmentsnormal-(xnormal-)normal-,hfragmentsnormal-(xnormal-)fragmentsnormal-)superscriptfragmentsnormal-(10productpnormal-)superscript106\max\bigl(h_{NT}(x),h(x)\bigl)\leq(10\prod p)^{10^{6}}

with the product taken over all bad reduction primes ppp of XXX. Here hN⁢TsubscripthNTh_{NT} is the Néron-Tate height and hhh is the stable Arakelov height, see Section 2. We also give in Proposition 3.4 and Proposition 5.3 versions of the above theorems with “exponentially smaller points”. These versions are either conditional on the a⁢b⁢cabcabc conjecture, or they depend on lower bounds for Faltings’ delta invariant which are not known to be effective.

We remark that “effective Siegel or Mordell” applications of our completely explicit results require hyperbolic curves which admit Kodaira-Paršin type constructions with all fibers in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}. There exists no hyperbolic curve for which Kodaira’s construction (see for example [, p.266]) is of this form and we are not aware of a hyperbolic curve for which Paršin’s construction (see Paršin [], or [, p.268]) has all fibers in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}. Therefore our results have at the moment no “effective Siegel or Mordell” applications. However, there is the hope that new and more suitable Kodaira-Paršin type constructions will be discovered. For example, recently Levin [] gave a new Paršin type construction for integral points on hyperelliptic curves with all fibers in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}.

The main ingredients for our proofs are as follows. Let XXX be a smooth, projective and geometrically connected curve of genus g≥2g2g\geq 2, defined over a number field KKK. On using fundamental results of Arakelov [], Faltings [] and Zhang [], we show that for any ϵ>0ϵ0\epsilon>0 there exist infinitely many algebraic points xxx of XXX that satisfy

hN⁢T⁢(x)≤2⁢g⁢(g-1)⁢h⁢(x)≤g⁢e⁢(X)+ϵ.subscripthNTx2gg1hxgeXϵh_{NT}(x)\leq 2g(g-1)h(x)\leq ge(X)+\epsilon. (1.1)

Here e⁢(X)eXe(X) is a certain stable Arakelov self-intersection number, defined in (4.1). Thus, to produce “small points” of XXX, it suffices to estimate e⁢(X)eXe(X) effectively in terms of K,SKSK,S and ggg, for SSS the set of finite places of KKK where XXX has bad reduction.

In the proof of Theorem 3.1 we use properties of the Belyi degree degB⁢(X)subscriptdegBX\textnormal{deg}_{B}(X) of XXX, which is defined in (4.2). From [, Theorem 1.1.1] we obtain

e⁢(X)≤108⁢degB⁢(X)5⁢g.eXsuperscript108subscriptdegBsuperscriptX5ge(X)\leq 10^{8}\textnormal{deg}_{B}(X)^{5}g. (1.2)

To control degB⁢(X)subscriptdegBX\textnormal{deg}_{B}(X) we use an effective version of Belyi’s theorem [], worked out by Khadjavi in []. We deduce an explicit upper bound for degB⁢(X)subscriptdegBX\textnormal{deg}_{B}(X) in terms of K,gKgK,g and the heights h⁢(λ)hλh(\lambda) of the cross-ratios λλ\lambda of four (geometric) branch points of a finite morphism X→ℙK1normal-→Xsubscriptsuperscriptℙ1KX\to\mathbb{P}^{1}_{K}. To estimate h⁢(λ)hλh(\lambda) we assume that X∈𝒞X𝒞X\in\mathcal{C} and then we combine [, Proposition 2.1] of de Jong-Rémond with [, Proposition 6.1 (ii)]. The latter result is based on the theory of logarithmic forms and the former result generalizes ideas of Paršin [] and Oort []. This leads to an explicit upper bound, in terms of K,SKSK,S and ggg, for degB⁢(X)subscriptdegBX\textnormal{deg}_{B}(X), then for e⁢(X)eXe(X) by (1.2), and then finally for hN⁢T⁢(x)subscripthNTxh_{NT}(x) and h⁢(x)hxh(x) by (1.1).

To discuss the proof of Theorem 3.3 we assume that g=2g2g=2. From [, Proposition 5.1 (v)] we obtain that Faltings’ delta invariant δ⁢(Xℂ)δsubscriptXℂ\delta(X_{\mathbb{C}}) of a compact connected Riemann surface XℂsubscriptXℂX_{\mathbb{C}} of genus two satisfies -186≤δ⁢(Xℂ).186δsubscriptXℂ-186\leq\delta(X_{\mathbb{C}}). Then the Noether formula for arithmetic surfaces, due to Faltings [] and Moret-Bailly [], leads to

e⁢(X)≤12⁢hF⁢(J)+201.eX12subscripthFJ201.e(X)\leq 12h_{F}(J)+201. (1.3)

Here hF⁢(J)subscripthFJh_{F}(J) is the absolute stable Faltings height of the Jacobian J=Pic0⁢(X)JsuperscriptPic0XJ=\textnormal{Pic}^{0}(X) of XXX. The inequalities in [, Proposition 4.1 (i), Proposition 6.1 (ii)] slightly refine a method developed by Paršin [], Oort [] and de Jong-Rémond []. On combining these inequalities, we deduce an explicit upper bound, in terms of K,SKSK,S and ggg, for hF⁢(J)subscripthFJh_{F}(J), then for e⁢(X)eXe(X) by (1.3), and then finally for hN⁢T⁢(x)subscripthNTxh_{NT}(x) and h⁢(x)hxh(x) by (1.1).

To prove Theorem 3.2 we replace in the proof of Theorem 3.3 the results from Arakelov theory by a formula of de Jong [, Theorem 4.3] and the explicit estimate for the hyperelliptic discriminant modular form which is given in [, Lemma 5.4].

The plan of this paper is as follows. In Section 2 we discuss Szpiro’s small points conjecture and its variation which involves the Néron-Tate height. In Section 3 we state our theorems, and we give Proposition 3.4 which is conditional on the a⁢b⁢cabcabc conjecture. Then in Section 4 we collect results from Arakelov theory for arithmetic surfaces. We also give an upper bound for the Belyi degree of XXX. In Section 5 we consider curves X∈𝒞X𝒞X\in\mathcal{C} and we prove Theorem 3.1. We also establish Proposition 5.3. It refines our theorems, with the disadvantage inherent that it involves a lower bound for Faltings’ delta invariant which is not known to be effective. In Section 6 we first show Lemma 6.1 and Lemma 6.2. They give explicit results for certain (Arakelov) invariants of hyperelliptic curves. Then we use these lemmas to prove Theorem 3.2. Finally, in Section 7, we give a proof of Theorem 3.3.

Throughout this paper we shall use the following notations and conventions. Let KKK be a number field. We denote by K¯normal-¯K\bar{K} a fixed algebraic closure of KKK. If LLL is a field extension of KKK, then we write [L:K]normal-:LK[L:K] for the relative degree of LLL over KKK. By a curve XXX over KKK we mean a smooth, projective and geometrically connected curve X→Spec⁢(K)normal-→XSpecKX\to\textnormal{Spec}(K). For any finite place vvv of KKK, we write NvsubscriptNvN_{v} for the number of elements in the residue field of vvv and we let v⁢(𝔞)v𝔞v(\mathfrak{a}) be the order of vvv in a fractional ideal 𝔞𝔞\mathfrak{a} of KKK. We denote by |S|S\lvert S\rvert the cardinality of a set SSS. Finally, by log\log we mean the principal value of the natural logarithm and we define the product taken over the empty set as 111.

2 Small points conjectures

In this section we state and discuss Szpiro’s small points conjecture, and its variation which involves the Néron-Tate height. Let KKK be a number field and let g≥2g2g\geq 2 be an integer. We denote by XXX a curve over KKK of genus ggg.

We take an algebraic point x∈X⁢(K¯)xXnormal-¯Kx\in X(\bar{K}). The classical result of Deligne-Mumford gives a finite extension LLL of KKK such that XLsubscriptXLX_{L} has semi-stable reduction over BBB and such that x∈X⁢(L)xXLx\in X(L), where BBB is the spectrum of the ring of integers of LLL. We denote by ω𝒳/Bsubscriptω𝒳B\omega_{\mathcal{X}/B} the relative dualizing sheaf of the minimal regular model 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} of XLsubscriptXLX_{L} over BBB. Let ω=(ω𝒳/B,∥⋅∥)ωsubscriptω𝒳Bnormnormal-⋅\omega=(\omega_{\mathcal{X}/B},\lVert\cdot\rVert) with ∥⋅∥normnormal-⋅\lVert\cdot\rVert the Arakelov metric, let (⋅,⋅)fragmentsnormal-(normal-⋅normal-,normal-⋅normal-)(\cdot,\cdot) be the intersection product of Arakelov divisors on 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and identify ωω\omega and xxx with the corresponding Arakelov divisors on 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, see [, Section 2] for definitions. Then the stable Arakelov height h⁢(x)hxh(x) of xxx is the real number defined by

[L:ℚ]h(x)=(ω,x).fragmentsfragmentsnormal-[Lnormal-:Qnormal-]hfragmentsnormal-(xnormal-)fragmentsnormal-(ωnormal-,xnormal-)normal-.[L:{\mathbb{Q}}]h(x)=(\omega,x). (2.1)

The factor [L:ℚ]normal-:Lℚ[L:{\mathbb{Q}}] and the semi-stability of 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} assure that the definition of h⁢(x)hxh(x) does not depend on the choice of a field LLL with the above properties.

Let SSS be a set of finite places of KKK. In 1984, Szpiro [, p.101] formulated his small points conjecture in terms of the Arakelov self-intersection (x,x)xx(x,x) of xxx. However, Arakelov’s adjunction formula (ω,x)=-(x,x)ωxxx(\omega,x)=-(x,x) in [] shows that Szpiro’s small points conjecture coincides with the following conjecture.

Conjecture (s⁢p)sp(sp). There exists an effective constant ccc, depending only on KKK, SSS and ggg, with the following property. Suppose XXX is a curve over KKK of genus ggg, with set of bad reduction places SSS. If XXX has semi-stable reduction over the ring of integers of KKK, then there is x∈X⁢(K¯)xXnormal-¯Kx\in X(\bar{K}) that satisfies h⁢(x)≤c.hxch(x)\leq c.

It is known (see Szpiro [, p.101]) that this conjecture implies an “effective Mordell conjecture”, and that Szpiro established a rather strong geometric analogue of Conjecture (s⁢pspsp) in []. We also mention that if Conjecture (s⁢pspsp) holds, then it holds without the semi-stable assumption. Indeed, on combining results of Grothendieck-Raynaud [, Proposition 4.7] and Serre-Tate [, Theorem 1] with Dedekind’s discriminant theorem, one obtains a finite field extension MMM of KKK such that XMsubscriptXMX_{M} has semi-stable reduction over the ring of integers of MMM and such that [M:K]normal-:MK[M:K] and the relative discriminant of MMM over KKK are effectively controlled in terms of KKK, SSS and ggg.

In the Grothendieck Festschrift, Szpiro [] formulated another version of Conjecture (s⁢p)sp(sp). This formulation involves the Néron-Tate height

hN⁢T⁢(x)subscripthNTxh_{NT}(x) (2.2)

of x∈X⁢(K¯)xXnormal-¯Kx\in X(\bar{K}) which is defined as the Néron-Tate height of the divisor class (2⁢g-2)⁢x-Ω12g2xsuperscriptnormal-Ω1(2g-2)x-\Omega^{1} in the Jacobian Pic0⁢(XL)superscriptPic0subscriptXL\textnormal{Pic}^{0}(X_{L}) of XLsubscriptXLX_{L} for LLL as above. Here Ω1superscriptnormal-Ω1\Omega^{1} denotes the sheaf of differential one-forms of the curve XLsubscriptXLX_{L} over LLL. We now give a version of Szpiro’s “Conjecture des deux petits points pour Néron-Tate” which is stated in [, p.244].

Conjecture (s⁢p)*superscriptsp(sp)^{*}. Any curve XXX over KKK of genus ggg has two distinct points xi∈X⁢(K¯)subscriptxiXnormal-¯Kx_{i}\in X(\bar{K}), i=1,2i12i=1,2, that satisfy hN⁢T⁢(xi)≤c,subscripthNTsubscriptxich_{NT}(x_{i})\leq c, where ccc is a constant which depends only on KKK, ggg and the geometry of the bad reduction of XXX.

We point out that the conjecture in [, p.244] describes the constant ccc in Conjecture (s⁢p)*superscriptsp(sp)^{*} more precisely. Szpiro conjectures in addition the existence of constants a⁢(g)aga(g), b⁢(g)bgb(g), depending only on ggg, and constants A⁢(X)AXA(X), B⁢(X)BXB(X), depending only on the geometry of the bad reduction of the curve XXX, such that

c=a⁢(g)⁢A⁢(X)⁢log⁡DK+b⁢(g)⁢B⁢(X).cagAXsubscriptDKbgBXc=a(g)A(X)\log D_{K}+b(g)B(X).

Here DKsubscriptDKD_{K} denotes the absolute value of the discriminant of KKK over ℚℚ{\mathbb{Q}}. Paršin [] showed that Conjecture (s⁢p)*superscriptsp(sp)^{*}, with ccc of the form as displayed above, implies Szpiro’s classical discriminant conjecture for elliptic curves. In addition, we mention that Moret-Bailly proposed a version of the small points conjecture which is equivalent to his adaption [, Hypothèse BM] of Paršin’s conjecture in [], see [, Corollaire 3.5]. The conjectures, which are considered in [] and [], are inspired by the classical Bogomolov-Miyaoka-Yau inequality for algebraic surfaces.

We shall see in Lemma 4.5 (i) that Conjecture (s⁢pspsp) implies Conjecture (s⁢p)*superscriptsp(sp)^{*}. An unconditional proof of the converse implication seems to be difficult. However, Szpiro’s arguments in [, p.244] combined with Moret-Bailly’s proof of [, Théorème 5.1] show that Conjecture (s⁢p)*superscriptsp(sp)^{*} still implies an “effective Mordell conjecture”.

Next, we discuss a possible dependence of the constants in Conjecture (s⁢pspsp) and Conjecture (s⁢p)*superscriptsp(sp)^{*} on the important quantities DKsubscriptDKD_{K} and NS=∏v∈SNvsubscriptNSsubscriptproductvSsubscriptNvN_{S}=\prod_{v\in S}N_{v}. We denote by hF⁢(A)subscripthFAh_{F}(A) the absolute stable Faltings height of an abelian variety AAA over ℚℚ{\mathbb{Q}} defined in [, p.354] and we denote by NAsubscriptNAN_{A} the norm of the usual conductor ideal of AAA. Now, we can state a version of Frey’s height conjecture [, p.39]. This version is inspired by its geometric analogue which is proven, for example, in Deligne [, p.14].

Conjecture (h)h(h). For any real ϵ>0ϵ0\epsilon>0 and any integer n≥1n1n\geq 1, there is a constant ccc, depending only on ϵ,nϵn\epsilon,n, such that if AAA is an abelian variety over ℚℚ{\mathbb{Q}} of dimension nnn, then hF⁢(A)≤(n2+ϵ)⁢log⁡NA+c.subscripthFAn2ϵsubscriptNAch_{F}(A)\leq(\frac{n}{2}+\epsilon)\log N_{A}+c.

Lemma 4.5 (ii) below shows that if Conjecture (h)h(h) holds for some fixed ϵ>0ϵ0\epsilon>0 and n=[K:ℚ]gfragmentsnfragmentsnormal-[Knormal-:Qnormal-]gn=[K:{\mathbb{Q}}]g, then there exists a constant c′superscriptcnormal-′c^{\prime}, depending only on [K:ℚ],gfragmentsfragmentsnormal-[Knormal-:Qnormal-]normal-,g[K:{\mathbb{Q}}],g and the fixed ϵϵ\epsilon, with the following property. Any curve XXX over KKK of genus ggg, with set of bad reduction places SSS, has an algebraic point x∈X⁢(K¯)xXnormal-¯Kx\in X(\bar{K}) that satisfies

h(x)≤3⁢gg-1(g+2⁢ϵ[K:ℚ])(logNS+logDK)+c′fragmentshfragmentsnormal-(xnormal-)3gg1fragmentsnormal-(g2ϵnormal-:Kℚfragmentsnormal-)fragmentsnormal-(subscriptNSsubscriptDKnormal-)superscriptcnormal-′h(x)\leq\frac{3g}{g-1}\bigl(g+\frac{2\epsilon}{[K:{\mathbb{Q}}]}\bigl)(\log N_% {S}+\log D_{K})+c^{\prime}

and has two distinct points xi∈X⁢(K¯)subscriptxiXnormal-¯Kx_{i}\in X(\bar{K}), i=1,2i12i=1,2, which both satisfy

hN⁢T(xi)≤12g2(g+2⁢ϵ[K:ℚ])(logNS+logDK)+c′.fragmentssubscripthNTfragmentsnormal-(subscriptxinormal-)12superscriptg2fragmentsnormal-(g2ϵnormal-:Kℚfragmentsnormal-)fragmentsnormal-(subscriptNSsubscriptDKnormal-)superscriptcnormal-′normal-.h_{NT}(x_{i})\leq 12g^{2}\bigl(g+\frac{2\epsilon}{[K:{\mathbb{Q}}]}\bigl)(\log N% _{S}+\log D_{K})+c^{\prime}.

This conditional result suggests a possible dependence of the constants in Conjecture (s⁢p)sp(sp) and (s⁢p)*superscriptsp(sp)^{*} on DKsubscriptDKD_{K} and NSsubscriptNSN_{S}. To conclude our discussion we mention that the rather strong geometric version of Conjecture (s⁢p)sp(sp), established by Szpiro (see [, p.101]), suggests even sharper upper bounds for h⁢(x)hxh(x) and hN⁢T⁢(xi)subscripthNTsubscriptxih_{NT}(x_{i}) in terms of DKsubscriptDKD_{K} and NSsubscriptNSN_{S}.

3 Statements of results

In this section we state and discuss Theorem 3.1, Theorem 3.2 and Theorem 3.3. We also give Proposition 3.4 which is conditional on the a⁢b⁢cabcabc conjecture.

To state our results we need to introduce some notation. Let g≥2g2g\geq 2 be an integer, let KKK be a number field and let SSS be a set of finite places of KKK. We denote by DKsubscriptDKD_{K} the absolute value of the discriminant of KKK over ℚℚ{\mathbb{Q}} and we denote by d=[K:ℚ]fragmentsdfragmentsnormal-[Knormal-:Qnormal-]d=[K:{\mathbb{Q}}] the degree of KKK over ℚℚ{\mathbb{Q}}. To measure KKK, SSS and ggg we use the quantities

DK, d, NS=∏v∈SNv, g  and  ν=d⁢(5⁢g)5.formulae-sequencesubscriptDKdsubscriptNSsubscriptproductvSsubscriptNvg and νdsuperscript5g5D_{K},\ d,\ N_{S}=\prod_{v\in S}N_{v},\ g\ \textnormal{ and }\ \nu=d(5g)^{5}. (3.1)

The only purpose of introducing νν\nu is to simplify the exposition. Let hhh be the stable Arakelov height and let hN⁢TsubscripthNTh_{NT} be the Néron-Tate height. These heights are defined in (2.1) and (2.2) respectively. Let 𝒞=𝒞⁢(K)𝒞𝒞K\mathcal{C}=\mathcal{C}(K) be the set of curves XXX over KKK of genus ≥2absent2\geq 2 such that there is a finite morphism X→ℙK1normal-→Xsubscriptsuperscriptℙ1KX\to\mathbb{P}^{1}_{K} of prime degree which is geometrically a cyclic cover. Our first theorem establishes in particular Conjecture (s⁢p)sp(sp) and (s⁢p)*superscriptsp(sp)^{*} for all X∈𝒞X𝒞X\in\mathcal{C}.

Theorem 3.1.

Let XXX be a curve over KKK of genus ggg, with set of bad reduction places SSS. If X∈𝒞X𝒞X\in\mathcal{C}, then there exist infinitely many x∈X⁢(K¯)xXnormal-¯Kx\in X(\bar{K}) that satisfy

logmax(hN⁢T(x),h(x))≤νd⁢ν(NSDK)ν.fragmentsfragmentsnormal-(subscripthNTfragmentsnormal-(xnormal-)normal-,hfragmentsnormal-(xnormal-)fragmentsnormal-)superscriptνdνsuperscriptfragmentsnormal-(subscriptNSsubscriptDKnormal-)νnormal-.\log\max\bigl(h_{NT}(x),h(x)\bigl)\leq\nu^{d\nu}(N_{S}D_{K})^{\nu}.

Next, we state two results which improve Theorem 3.1 in certain cases. We say that a curve XXX over KKK of genus ggg is a hyperelliptic curve over KKK if there is a finite morphism X→ℙK1normal-→Xsubscriptsuperscriptℙ1KX\to\mathbb{P}^{1}_{K} of degree two. For example, any genus two curve over KKK is a hyperelliptic curve over KKK. We obtain the following theorem for hyperelliptic curves.

Theorem 3.2.

Let XXX be a hyperelliptic curve over KKK of genus ggg, with set of bad reduction places SSS. If 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} denotes the set of Weierstrass points of XXX, then

∑x∈𝒲hN⁢T⁢(x)≤ν8g⁢d⁢ν⁢(NS⁢DK)ν.subscriptx𝒲subscripthNTxsuperscriptνsuperscript8gdνsuperscriptsubscriptNSsubscriptDKν\sum_{x\in\mathcal{W}}h_{NT}(x)\leq\nu^{8^{g}d\nu}(N_{S}D_{K})^{\nu}.

The Néron-Tate height hN⁢TsubscripthNTh_{NT} is non-negative, and any hyperelliptic curve over KKK of genus ggg has exactly 2⁢g+22g22g+2 Weierstrass points. Thus Theorem 3.2 gives another proof of Conjecture (s⁢p)*superscriptsp(sp)^{*} for all hyperelliptic curves over KKK of genus ggg. The next result refines Theorem 3.1 in the special case of genus two curves.

Theorem 3.3.

Suppose XXX is a curve over KKK of genus two, with set of bad reduction places SSS. Then there exist infinitely many x∈X⁢(K¯)xXnormal-¯Kx\in X(\bar{K}) that satisfy

max(hN⁢T(x),h(x))≤ν2⁢d⁢ν(NSDK)ν,ν=105d.fragmentsfragmentsnormal-(subscripthNTfragmentsnormal-(xnormal-)normal-,hfragmentsnormal-(xnormal-)fragmentsnormal-)superscriptν2dνsuperscriptfragmentsnormal-(subscriptNSsubscriptDKnormal-)νnormal-,νsuperscript105dnormal-.\max\bigl(h_{NT}(x),h(x)\bigl)\leq\nu^{2d\nu}(N_{S}D_{K})^{\nu},\ \ \ \nu=10^{% 5}d.

To state Proposition 3.4 we need to recall the a⁢b⁢cabcabc-conjecture of Masser-Oesterlé [] over number fields. For any non-zero triple α,β,γ∈KαβγK\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in K we denote by H⁢(α,β,γ)HαβγH(\alpha,\beta,\gamma) the usual absolute multiplicative Weil height of the corresponding point in ℙ2⁢(K)superscriptℙ2K\mathbb{P}^{2}(K), see [, 1.5.4]. We define the height function HK=HdsubscriptHKsuperscriptHdH_{K}=H^{d} and we write SK⁢(α,β,γ)=∏NvevsubscriptSKαβγproductsuperscriptsubscriptNvsubscriptevS_{K}(\alpha,\beta,\gamma)=\prod N_{v}^{e_{v}} with the product extended over all finite places vvv of KKK such that v⁢(α)vαv(\alpha), v⁢(β)vβv(\beta) and v⁢(γ)vγv(\gamma) are not all equal, where ev=v⁢(p)subscriptevvpe_{v}=v(p) for ppp the residue characteristic of vvv. We mention that Masser [] added the ramification index evsubscripteve_{v} in the definition of the support SKsubscriptSKS_{K} to obtain a natural behaviour of SKsubscriptSKS_{K} under finite field extensions.

Conjecture (a⁢b⁢cabcabc). For any integer n≥1n1n\geq 1, and any real r,ϵ>1rϵ1r,\epsilon>1, there is a constant ccc, which depends only on n,r,ϵnrϵn,r,\epsilon, such that if KKK is a number field of degree [K:ℚ]≤nfragmentsfragmentsnormal-[Knormal-:Qnormal-]n[K:{\mathbb{Q}}]\leq n, and α,β,γ∈KαβγK\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in K are non-zero and satisfy α+β=γαβγ\alpha+\beta=\gamma, then HK⁢(α,β,γ)≤c⁢SK⁢(α,β,γ)r⁢DKϵ.subscriptHKαβγcsubscriptSKsuperscriptαβγrsuperscriptsubscriptDKϵH_{K}(\alpha,\beta,\gamma)\leq cS_{K}(\alpha,\beta,\gamma)^{r}D_{K}^{\epsilon}.

The following proposition is conditional on Conjecture (a⁢b⁢c)abc(abc). It improves exponentially, in terms of NSsubscriptNSN_{S} and DKsubscriptDKD_{K}, the inequalities in our theorems. We put u⁢(g)=8(11⁢g)3⁢8g.ugsuperscript8superscript11g3superscript8gu(g)=8^{(11g)^{3}8^{g}}.

Proposition 3.4.

Let r,ϵ>1rϵ1r,\epsilon>1 be real numbers and write

Ω=(r+ϵd)⁢log⁡NS+ϵd⁢log⁡DK.normal-ΩrϵdsubscriptNSϵdsubscriptDK\Omega=(r+\frac{\epsilon}{d})\log N_{S}+\frac{\epsilon}{d}\log D_{K}.

Suppose Conjecture (a⁢b⁢c)abc(abc) holds for n=24⁢g4⁢d,r,ϵn24superscriptg4drϵn=24g^{4}d,r,\epsilon with the constant ccc. Then there exist effective constants c1,c2,c3subscriptc1subscriptc2subscriptc3c_{1},c_{2},c_{3}, depending only on c,r,ϵ,dcrϵdc,r,\epsilon,d and ggg, such that for any curve XXX over KKK of genus ggg, with set of bad reduction places SSS, the following statements hold.

  • (i)

    If X∈𝒞X𝒞X\in\mathcal{C}, then there are infinitely many points x∈X⁢(K¯)xXnormal-¯Kx\in X(\bar{K}) that satisfy

    logmax(hN⁢T(x),h(x))≤ννΩ+c1.fragmentsfragmentsnormal-(subscripthNTfragmentsnormal-(xnormal-)normal-,hfragmentsnormal-(xnormal-)fragmentsnormal-)superscriptννΩsubscriptc1normal-.\log\max\bigl(h_{NT}(x),h(x)\bigl)\leq\nu^{\nu}\Omega+c_{1}.
  • (ii)

    If XXX is a hyperelliptic curve over KKK, with set of Weierstrass points 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W}, then

    ∑x∈𝒲hN⁢T⁢(x)≤u⁢(g)⁢(3⁢g-1)⁢(8⁢g+4)⁢Ω+c2.subscriptx𝒲subscripthNTxug3g18g4normal-Ωsubscriptc2\sum_{x\in\mathcal{W}}h_{NT}(x)\leq u(g)(3g-1)(8g+4)\Omega+c_{2}.
  • (iii)

    If g=2g2g=2, then there are infinitely many points x∈X⁢(K¯)xXnormal-¯Kx\in X(\bar{K}) that satisfy

    14⁢hN⁢T⁢(x)≤h⁢(x)≤6⁢u⁢(2)⁢Ω+c3.14subscripthNTxhx6u2normal-Ωsubscriptc3\frac{1}{4}h_{NT}(x)\leq h(x)\leq 6u(2)\Omega+c_{3}.

This proposition only requires the validity of (a⁢b⁢c)abc(abc) for some fixed n,r,ϵnrϵn,r,\epsilon, instead of all n,r,ϵnrϵn,r,\epsilon, and (a⁢b⁢c)abc(abc) with fixed n,r,ϵnrϵn,r,\epsilon is often called “weak a⁢b⁢cabcabc conjecture”.

We mention that the factor u⁢(g)ugu(g), which appears in Proposition 3.4, is not optimal. Its origin shall be explained after Proposition 5.3.

In general, we conducted some effort to obtain constants reasonably close to the best that can be acquired with the present method of proof. However, to simplify the form of our inequalities we freely rounded off several of the numbers in our estimates.

4 Self-intersection, Belyi degree and heights

In the first part of this section we give two lemmas which describe properties of the Belyi degree, and in the second part we collect results from Arakelov theory for arithmetic surfaces. We also prove a lemma which was used in Section 2. Throughout this section we denote by XXX a curve of genus g≥2g2g\geq 2, defined over a number field KKK.

If LLL, ωω\omega and (⋅,⋅)fragmentsnormal-(normal-⋅normal-,normal-⋅normal-)(\cdot,\cdot) are as in Section 2, then the stable self-intersection e⁢(X)eXe(X) of ωω\omega is the real number defined by

We observe that this definition does not depend on any choices. Let DDD be the set of degrees of finite morphisms XK¯→ℙK¯1normal-→subscriptXnormal-¯Ksubscriptsuperscriptℙ1normal-¯KX_{\bar{K}}\to\mathbb{P}^{1}_{\bar{K}} which are unramified outside 0,1,∞010,1,\infty. Belyi’s theorem [] shows that DDD is non-empty. The Belyi degree degB⁢(X)subscriptdegBX\textnormal{deg}_{B}(X) of XXX is defined by

degB⁢(X)=min⁡D.subscriptdegBXD\textnormal{deg}_{B}(X)=\min D. (4.2)

Our proof of Theorem 3.1 uses two fundamental properties of the Belyi degree. We now state the first of these properties in the following lemma.

Lemma 4.1.

It holds e⁢(X)≤108⁢degB⁢(X)5⁢geXsuperscript108subscriptdegBsuperscriptX5ge(X)\leq 10^{8}\textnormal{deg}_{B}(X)^{5}g.

Proof.

The statement is proven in [, Theorem 1.1.1]. ∎

The next lemma gives the second property. It is a consequence of an effective version of Belyi’s theorem [] worked out by Khadjavi []. We mention that the bound in Khadjavi’s [, Theorem 1.1], and thus Lemma 4.2, can be improved in special cases. See for example Liţcanu [].

Let hhh be the stable Arakelov height from (2.1). To obtain infinitely many small points we shall use the following lemma which relies on a fundamental result of Zhang [].

Lemma 4.3.

The following lemma is a direct consequence of classical results of Arakelov [], Faltings [] and Moret-Bailly []. To state this lemma we introduce further notation. cδ⁢(g).subscriptcδgc_{\delta}(g). (4.3)

We now prove (ii). If vvv is a closed point of BBB, then we denote by δvsubscriptδv\delta_{v} the number of singular points of the geometric special fiber of 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} over vvv. The (logarithmic) stable discriminant Δ⁢(X)normal-ΔX\Delta(X) of XXX is the real number defined by

The final lemma of this section proves two results which were used in our discussion of Conjecture (s⁢p)sp(sp) and (s⁢p)*superscriptsp(sp)^{*} in Section 2. Let SSS be the set of finite places of KKK where XXX has bad reduction, and let DKsubscriptDKD_{K}, ddd and NSsubscriptNSN_{S} be the quantities defined in (3.1).

Lemma 4.5.

Suppose ϵ>0ϵ0\epsilon>0 is a real number. Then the following statements hold.

  • (i)

    For any x0∈X⁢(K¯)subscriptx0Xnormal-¯Kx_{0}\in X(\bar{K}), there are infinitely many x∈X⁢(K¯)xXnormal-¯Kx\in X(\bar{K}) that satisfy

  • (ii)

    Suppose that Conjecture (h)h(h) holds for ϵϵ\epsilon and n=d⁢gndgn=dg with the constant ccc. Then there is an effective constant κκ\kappa, depending only on c,ϵ,d,gcϵdgc,\epsilon,d,g, with the following properties. There exists x0∈X⁢(K¯)subscriptx0Xnormal-¯Kx_{0}\in X(\bar{K}) that satisfies

    h(x0)≤3⁢gg-1(g+2⁢ϵd)(logNS+logDK)-cδ⁢(g)4⁢(g-1)+κfragmentshfragmentsnormal-(subscriptx0normal-)3gg1fragmentsnormal-(g2ϵdfragmentsnormal-)fragmentsnormal-(subscriptNSsubscriptDKnormal-)subscriptcδg4g1κh(x_{0})\leq\frac{3g}{g-1}\bigl(g+\frac{2\epsilon}{d}\bigl)(\log N_{S}+\log D_% {K})-\frac{c_{\delta}(g)}{4(g-1)}+\kappa

    and there exist infinitely many points x∈X⁢(K¯)xXnormal-¯Kx\in X(\bar{K}) that satisfy

    hN⁢T(x)≤12g2(g+2⁢ϵd)(logNS+logDK)-gcδ(g)+κ.fragmentssubscripthNTfragmentsnormal-(xnormal-)12superscriptg2fragmentsnormal-(g2ϵdfragmentsnormal-)fragmentsnormal-(subscriptNSsubscriptDKnormal-)gsubscriptcδfragmentsnormal-(gnormal-)κnormal-.h_{NT}(x)\leq 12g^{2}\bigl(g+\frac{2\epsilon}{d}\bigl)(\log N_{S}+\log D_{K})-% gc_{\delta}(g)+\kappa.
Proof.

We first prove (i). On combining Lemma 4.3 with Lemma 4.4 (i), we obtain infinitely many points x∈X⁢(K¯)xXnormal-¯Kx\in X(\bar{K}) that satisfy

To show (ii) we may and do assume that Conjecture (h)h(h) holds for ϵϵ\epsilon and n=d⁢gndgn=dg with the constant ccc. The Weil restriction A=ResK/ℚ⁢(J)AsubscriptResKℚJA=\textnormal{Res}_{K/{\mathbb{Q}}}(J) of the Jacobian JJJ of XXX is an abelian variety over ℚℚ{\mathbb{Q}} of dimension nnn, which is geometrically isomorphic to ∏JσproductsuperscriptJσ\prod J^{\sigma}. dhF(J)≤(n2+ϵ)logNA+c.fragmentsdsubscripthFfragmentsnormal-(Jnormal-)fragmentsnormal-(n2ϵfragmentsnormal-)subscriptNAcnormal-.dh_{F}(J)\leq\bigl(\frac{n}{2}+\epsilon\bigl)\log N_{A}+c.

e(X)≤12g(g+2⁢ϵd)(logNS+logDK)-cδ(g)+κ2,fragmentsefragmentsnormal-(Xnormal-)12gfragmentsnormal-(g2ϵdfragmentsnormal-)fragmentsnormal-(subscriptNSsubscriptDKnormal-)subscriptcδfragmentsnormal-(gnormal-)subscriptκ2normal-,e(X)\leq 12g\bigl(g+\frac{2\epsilon}{d}\bigl)(\log N_{S}+\log D_{K})-c_{\delta% }(g)+\kappa_{2},

where κ2subscriptκ2\kappa_{2} is an effective constant depending only on c,ϵ,dcϵdc,\epsilon,d and ggg. There exists an algebraic point x0∈X⁢(K¯)subscriptx0Xnormal-¯Kx_{0}\in X(\bar{K}) with 4⁢(g-1)⁢h⁢(x0)≤e⁢(X)+ϵ4g1hsubscriptx0eXϵ4(g-1)h(x_{0})\leq e(X)+\epsilon, see the proof of [, Proposition 3.4]. Therefore the displayed upper bound for e⁢(X)eXe(X) together with (4.5) implies assertion (ii). This completes the proof of Lemma 4.5. ∎

We conclude this section by the following remarks. Suppose there exists a finite morphism φ:X→ℙK1normal-:φnormal-→Xsubscriptsuperscriptℙ1K\varphi:X\to\mathbb{P}^{1}_{K}, with deg⁢(φ)degφ\textnormal{deg}(\varphi) and HΛsubscriptHnormal-ΛH_{\Lambda} effectively bounded in terms of KKK, SSS and ggg, where HΛsubscriptHnormal-ΛH_{\Lambda} is the height of the set Λnormal-Λ\Lambda of (geometric) branch points of φφ\varphi. Then Lemma 4.1, Lemma 4.2 and Lemma 4.3 show that XXX has infinitely many “small points”, and therefore XXX satisfies in particular Szpiro’s small points conjecture.

Similarly, if degB⁢(X)subscriptdegBX\textnormal{deg}_{B}(X) is effectively bounded in terms of KKK, SSS and ggg, then Lemma 4.1 and Lemma 4.3 show that XXX has infinitely many “small points”. For example, if the base change of XXX to ℂℂ{\mathbb{C}}, with respect to some embedding K↪ℂnormal-↪KℂK\hookrightarrow{\mathbb{C}}, is a classical congruence modular curve, then a result of Zograf in [] gives degB⁢(X)≤128⁢(g+1)subscriptdegBX128g1\textnormal{deg}_{B}(X)\leq 128(g+1).

5 Cyclic covers of prime degree

In this section we prove Theorem 3.1 and Proposition 3.4 (i). We also give Proposition 5.3 which may be of independent interest. It improves the inequalities in Theorem 3.1 and Proposition 3.4 (i), with the disadvantage inherent that it involves a constant which is not known to be effective.

Let XXX be a curve over a number field KKK of genus g≥2g2g\geq 2, let SSS be the set of finite places of KKK where XXX has bad reduction and let 𝒞=𝒞⁢(K)𝒞𝒞K\mathcal{C}=\mathcal{C}(K) be the set of cyclic covers of prime degree from Section 3. In this section we assume throughout that X∈𝒞X𝒞X\in\mathcal{C}.

We now give two lemmas which will be used in our proof of Theorem 3.1. To state and prove these lemmas we have to introduce some notation. Our assumption that X∈𝒞X𝒞X\in\mathcal{C} provides a finite morphism φ:X→ℙK1normal-:φnormal-→Xsubscriptsuperscriptℙ1K\varphi:X\to\mathbb{P}^{1}_{K} which is geometrically a cyclic cover of prime degree. Let qqq be the degree of φφ\varphi and let LLL be a finite extension of KKK. We denote by U=S⁢(L,q)USLqU=S(L,q) the set of places of LLL which divide qqq or a place in SSS. Let 𝒪U×superscriptsubscript𝒪U\mathcal{O}_{U}^{\times} be the UUU-units in LLL and let h⁢(α)hαh(\alpha) be the usual absolute logarithmic Weil height of α∈LαL\alpha\in L, defined in [, 1.6.1]. We define the quantity μU=sup(h(λ),λ∈𝒪U× and 1-λ∈𝒪U×)fragmentssubscriptμUsupremumfragmentsnormal-(hfragmentsnormal-(λnormal-)normal-,λsuperscriptsubscript𝒪U and 1λsuperscriptsubscript𝒪Unormal-)\mu_{U}=\sup(h(\lambda),\lambda\in\mathcal{O}_{U}^{\times}\textnormal{ and }1-% \lambda\in\mathcal{O}_{U}^{\times}). Let ℛℛ\mathcal{R} be the set of field extensions LLL of KKK such that LLL is the compositum of the fields of definition of four distinct (geometric) ramification points of φφ\varphi. Then we define

μX=sup⁡(1,μS⁢(L,q))subscriptμXsupremum1subscriptμSLq\mu_{X}=\sup(1,\mu_{S(L,q)}) (5.1)

with the supremum taken over all fields L∈ℛLℛL\in\mathcal{R}. Let degB⁢(X)subscriptdegBX\textnormal{deg}_{B}(X) be the Belyi degree of XXX, defined in (4.2), and let ddd be the degree of KKK over ℚℚ{\mathbb{Q}}.

Lemma 5.1.

If ν=d⁢(5⁢g)5νdsuperscript5g5\nu=d(5g)^{5}, then log⁡degB⁢(X)≤νν/2⁢μXsubscriptdegBXsuperscriptνν2subscriptμX\log\textnormal{deg}_{B}(X)\leq\nu^{\nu/2}\mu_{X}.

To prove this lemma we shall combine the estimate for degB⁢(X)subscriptdegBX\textnormal{deg}_{B}(X) in Lemma 4.2 with the following observation of Paršin in []: The cross-ratios of the branch points, of a hyperelliptic map of a genus two curve XXX over KKK, are solutions of certain S⁢(L,2)SL2S(L,2)-unit equations. Oort [, Lemma 2.1] and de Jong-Rémond [, Proposition 2.1] generalized Paršin’s idea to hyperelliptic curves and to cyclic covers of prime degree.

Proof of Lemma 5.1.

We take three distinct (geometric) ramification points of φφ\varphi. Let MMM be the compositum of their fields of definition. On composing φφ\varphi with a suitable automorphism of ℙM1subscriptsuperscriptℙ1M\mathbb{P}^{1}_{M}, we get a finite morphism XM→ℙM1normal-→subscriptXMsubscriptsuperscriptℙ1MX_{M}\to\mathbb{P}^{1}_{M} of degree qqq such that {0,1,∞}⊂Λ01normal-Λ\{0,1,\infty\}\subset\Lambda, where Λnormal-Λ\Lambda is the set of (geometric) branch points of φφ\varphi. Let HΛsubscriptHnormal-ΛH_{\Lambda} be the height of Λnormal-Λ\Lambda, defined in Section 4. To prove the inequality

log⁡HΛ≤μX,subscriptHnormal-ΛsubscriptμX\log H_{\Lambda}\leq\mu_{X},

we may and do take λ∈Λλnormal-Λ\lambda\in\Lambda with λ≠0,1,∞λ01\lambda\neq 0,1,\infty. We write U=S⁢(K⁢(λ),q)USKλqU=S(K(\lambda),q). From [, Proposition 2.1] we deduce that the cross-ratios λ=cr⁢(∞,0,1,λ)λcr01λ\lambda=\textnormal{cr}(\infty,0,1,\lambda) and 1-λ=cr⁢(∞,1,0,λ)1λcr10λ1-\lambda=\textnormal{cr}(\infty,1,0,\lambda) are UUU-units in K⁢(λ)KλK(\lambda). This implies that h⁢(λ)≤μXhλsubscriptμXh(\lambda)\leq\mu_{X}, since K⁢(λ)⊆LKλLK(\lambda)\subseteq L for some L∈ℛLℛL\in\mathcal{R}. Hence we obtain log⁡HΛ≤μXsubscriptHnormal-ΛsubscriptμX\log H_{\Lambda}\leq\mu_{X} as desired. Next, we observe that the ramification indexes of φK¯:XK¯→ℙK¯1normal-:subscriptφnormal-¯Knormal-→subscriptXnormal-¯Ksubscriptsuperscriptℙ1normal-¯K\varphi_{\bar{K}}:X_{\bar{K}}\to\mathbb{P}^{1}_{\bar{K}} are in {1,q}1q\{1,q\}, and Gal⁢(K¯/K)Galnormal-¯KK\textnormal{Gal}(\bar{K}/K) acts on the (geometric) ramification points of φφ\varphi. Therefore Hurwitz leads to q≤2⁢g+1q2g1q\leq 2g+1 and [M:ℚ]≤15dg3fragmentsfragmentsnormal-[Mnormal-:Qnormal-]15dsuperscriptg3[M:{\mathbb{Q}}]\leq 15dg^{3}. Then an application of Lemma 4.2 with XM→ℙM1normal-→subscriptXMsubscriptsuperscriptℙ1MX_{M}\to\mathbb{P}^{1}_{M} gives an upper bound for degB⁢(X)subscriptdegBX\textnormal{deg}_{B}(X) which together with the displayed inequality implies Lemma 5.1. ∎

We remark that if L∈ℛLℛL\in\mathcal{R}, then Hurwitz (see the proof of Lemma 5.1) leads to q≤2⁢g+1q2g1q\leq 2g+1 and [L:K]≤24g4,fragmentsfragmentsnormal-[Lnormal-:Knormal-]24superscriptg4normal-,[L:K]\leq 24g^{4}, and [, Lemme 2.1] of de Jong-Rémond implies that LLL is unramified outside S⁢(K,q)SKqS(K,q).

Next, we go into number theory and we give an upper bound for μXsubscriptμX\mu_{X} in terms of the quantities NSsubscriptNSN_{S}, νν\nu, ddd and DKsubscriptDKD_{K} which are defined in (3.1).

Lemma 5.2.

The following statements hold.

  • (i)

    It holds μX≤νd⁢ν/8⁢(NS⁢DK)νsubscriptμXsuperscriptνdν8superscriptsubscriptNSsubscriptDKν\mu_{X}\leq\nu^{d\nu/8}(N_{S}D_{K})^{\nu}.

  • (ii)

    Let r,ϵ>1rϵ1r,\epsilon>1 be real numbers. Suppose (a⁢b⁢c)abc(abc) holds for n=24⁢g4⁢d,r,ϵn24superscriptg4drϵn=24g^{4}d,r,\epsilon with the constant ccc. Then there exists an effective constant c*superscriptcc^{*}, depending only on c,r,ϵ,dcrϵdc,r,\epsilon,d and ggg, such that d⁢μX≤(d⁢r+ϵ)⁢log⁡NS+ϵ⁢log⁡DK+c*.dsubscriptμXdrϵsubscriptNSϵsubscriptDKsuperscriptcd\mu_{X}\leq(dr+\epsilon)\log N_{S}+\epsilon\log D_{K}+c^{*}.

To prove (i) we use [, Proposition 6.1 (ii)]. It is based on the theory of logarithmic forms and we refer to the monograph of Baker-Wüstholz [] in which the state of the art of this theory is exposed.

Proof of Lemma 5.2.

We take L∈ℛLℛL\in\mathcal{R}, and we write U=S⁢(L,q)USLqU=S(L,q), T=S⁢(K,q)TSKqT=S(K,q) and l=[L:K]fragmentslfragmentsnormal-[Lnormal-:Knormal-]l=[L:K]. We now apply [, Proposition 6.1] with U=UUUU=U, T=TTTT=T and S=TSTS=T, where the symbols U,T,SUTSU,T,S on the left hand side of these equalities denote the sets in [, Proposition 6.1]. To show statement (ii) we take real numbers r,ϵ>1rϵ1r,\epsilon>1. We may and do assume that Conjecture (a⁢b⁢c)abc(abc) holds for n=24⁢g4⁢d,r,ϵn24superscriptg4drϵn=24g^{4}d,r,\epsilon with the constant ccc. Then Conjecture (a⁢b⁢c)abc(abc) holds in particular for n′=l⁢d,r,ϵsuperscriptnnormal-′ldrϵn^{\prime}=ld,r,\epsilon with the same constant ccc, since n′≤nsuperscriptnnormal-′nn^{\prime}\leq n. Therefore we see that [, Proposition 6.1 (iii)] gives

d⁢μU≤(d⁢r+ϵ)⁢log⁡NT+ϵ⁢log⁡DK+ϵ⁢d⁢t⁢log⁡l-ϵl⁢log⁡NT+1l⁢log⁡cdsubscriptμUdrϵsubscriptNTϵsubscriptDKϵdtlϵlsubscriptNT1lcd\mu_{U}\leq(dr+\epsilon)\log N_{T}+\epsilon\log D_{K}+\epsilon dt\log l-\frac% {\epsilon}{l}\log N_{T}+\frac{1}{l}\log c

for t=|T|tTt=\lvert T\rvert. From [, Lemma 6.3] we get that ϵ⁢d⁢t⁢log⁡l-ϵl⁢log⁡NTϵdtlϵlsubscriptNT\epsilon dt\log l-\frac{\epsilon}{l}\log N_{T} is bounded from above by an effective constant, which depends only on ϵ,dϵd\epsilon,d and ggg. Hence we deduce statement (ii) and this completes the proof of Lemma 5.2. ∎

We recall that hhh denotes the stable Arakelov height and that hN⁢TsubscripthNTh_{NT} denotes the Néron-Tate height. These heights are defined in (2.1) and (2.2) respectively. We now prove Theorem 3.1 and Proposition 3.4 (i) simultaneously.

Proof of Theorem 3.1 and Proposition 3.4 (i).

On combining Lemma 4.1, Lemma 4.3, Lemma 4.4 and Lemma 5.1, we obtain infinitely many x∈X⁢(K¯)xXnormal-¯Kx\in X(\bar{K}) that satisfy logmax(hN⁢T(x),h(x))≤6νν/2μX.fragmentsfragmentsnormal-(subscripthNTfragmentsnormal-(xnormal-)normal-,hfragmentsnormal-(xnormal-)fragmentsnormal-)6superscriptνν2subscriptμXnormal-.\log\max\bigl(h_{NT}(x),h(x)\bigl)\leq 6\nu^{\nu/2}\mu_{X}. Then Lemma 5.2 (i) and Lemma 5.2 (ii) imply Theorem 3.1 (i) and Proposition 3.4 (i) respectively. ∎

The remaining of this section is devoted to the following Proposition 5.3. Let cδ⁢(g)subscriptcδgc_{\delta}(g) be the minimum of Faltings’ delta invariant on Mg⁢(ℂ)subscriptMgℂM_{g}({\mathbb{C}}), defined in (4.3). We recall that if g≥3g3g\geq 3, then effective lower bounds for cδ⁢(g)subscriptcδgc_{\delta}(g) in terms of ggg are not known. We write u⁢(g)=8(11⁢g)3⁢8gugsuperscript8superscript11g3superscript8gu(g)=8^{(11g)^{3}8^{g}} and now we can state the following result.

Proposition 5.3.

The following statements hold.

  • (i)

    There are infinitely many x∈X⁢(K¯)xXnormal-¯Kx\in X(\bar{K}) that satisfy

    h⁢(x)≤ν8g⁢d⁢ν⁢(DK⁢NS)ν-cδ⁢(g).hxsuperscriptνsuperscript8gdνsuperscriptsubscriptDKsubscriptNSνsubscriptcδgh(x)\leq\nu^{8^{g}d\nu}(D_{K}N_{S})^{\nu}-c_{\delta}(g).
  • (ii)

    Let r,ϵ>1rϵ1r,\epsilon>1 be real numbers. Suppose Conjecture (a⁢b⁢c)abc(abc) holds for n=24⁢g4⁢d,r,ϵn24superscriptg4drϵn=24g^{4}d,r,\epsilon with the constant ccc. Then there exists an effective constant c1′superscriptsubscriptc1normal-′c_{1}^{\prime}, depending only on c,r,ϵ,dcrϵdc,r,\epsilon,d and ggg, with the property that there are infinitely many points x∈X⁢(K¯)xXnormal-¯Kx\in X(\bar{K}) which satisfy

    h(x)≤6u⁢(g)g-1((r+ϵd)logNS+ϵdlogDK)+c1′-cδ⁢(g)2⁢g-2.fragmentshfragmentsnormal-(xnormal-)6ugg1fragmentsnormal-(fragmentsnormal-(rϵdnormal-)subscriptNSϵdsubscriptDKfragmentsnormal-)superscriptsubscriptc1normal-′subscriptcδg2g2normal-.h(x)\leq 6\frac{u(g)}{g-1}\bigl((r+\frac{\epsilon}{d})\log N_{S}+\frac{% \epsilon}{d}\log D_{K}\bigl)+c_{1}^{\prime}-\frac{c_{\delta}(g)}{2g-2}.

These (ineffective) inequalities improve exponentially, in terms of NSsubscriptNSN_{S} and DKsubscriptDKD_{K}, the estimates provided by Theorem 3.1 and Proposition 3.4 (i). On using Lemma 4.4 one can formulate Proposition 5.3 also in terms of hN⁢TsubscripthNTh_{NT}. We mention that the factor u⁢(g)ugu(g) comes from explicit height comparisons of Rémond [] which rely inter alia on results of Bost-David-Pazuki []. Rémond’s explicit height comparisons hold for arbitrary curves over KKK and in our special case X∈𝒞X𝒞X\in\mathcal{C} it seems possible to improve these height comparisons, and thus u⁢(g)ugu(g), up to a certain extent.

To prove Proposition 5.3 we use the following tools. We combine Lemma 5.2 with [, Proposition 4.1 (i)]. This slightly refines the method developed by Paršin [], Oort [] and de Jong-Rémond []. We also use Lemma 4.3 which is based on a theorem of Zhang [], and Lemma 4.4 (ii) which relies on Moret-Bailly’s refinement [] of the Noether formula in Faltings’ article [].

Proof of Proposition 5.3.

Let hF⁢(J)subscripthFJh_{F}(J) be the absolute stable Faltings height of the Jacobian JJJ of XXX. The remark below [, Proposition 4 (i)] gives

hF⁢(J)≤u⁢(g)⁢μX.subscripthFJugsubscriptμXh_{F}(J)\leq u(g)\mu_{X}. (5.2)

Then Lemma 4.4 (ii) shows e⁢(X)≤12⁢u⁢(g)⁢μX-cδ⁢(g)+4⁢g⁢log⁡(2⁢π)eX12ugsubscriptμXsubscriptcδg4g2πe(X)\leq 12u(g)\mu_{X}-c_{\delta}(g)+4g\log(2\pi) for e⁢(X)eXe(X) as in (4.1). Hence Lemma 4.3 and Lemma 5.2 imply Proposition 5.3. ∎

We conclude this section by the following remarks. Let hF⁢(J)subscripthFJh_{F}(J) be as above, let Δ⁢(X)normal-ΔX\Delta(X) be the stable discriminant of XXX defined in (4.4) and let e⁢(X)eXe(X) be as in (4.1). Further, we define the quantity δ⁢(X)=1d⁢∑δ⁢(Xσ)δX1dδsubscriptXσ\delta(X)=\frac{1}{d}\sum\delta(X_{\sigma}) with the sum taken over all embeddings σ:K↪ℂnormal-:σnormal-↪Kℂ\sigma:K\hookrightarrow{\mathbb{C}}, where δ⁢(Xσ)δsubscriptXσ\delta(X_{\sigma}) is defined in Section 4. Then it holds

log⁢max⁡(e⁢(X),δ⁢(X),hF⁢(J),Δ⁢(X))≤νd⁢ν⁢(DK⁢NS)ν.eXδXsubscripthFJnormal-ΔXsuperscriptνdνsuperscriptsubscriptDKsubscriptNSν\log\max(e(X),\delta(X),h_{F}(J),\Delta(X))\leq\nu^{d\nu}(D_{K}N_{S})^{\nu}. (5.3)

Indeed [, Theorem 1.1.1] gives that max⁡(e⁢(X),δ⁢(X),hF⁢(J),Δ⁢(X))eXδXsubscripthFJnormal-ΔX\max(e(X),\delta(X),h_{F}(J),\Delta(X)) is at most 109⁢g2⁢degB⁢(X)5superscript109superscriptg2subscriptdegBsuperscriptX510^{9}g^{2}\textnormal{deg}_{B}(X)^{5} and then Lemma 5.1 and Lemma 5.2 prove the displayed inequality.

Next, we mention that de Jong-Rémond obtained in [, Theorem 1.2] a better estimate for hF⁢(J)subscripthFJh_{F}(J) and that [, Theorem 3.2] gives an exponential better upper bound for Δ⁢(X)normal-ΔX\Delta(X). The latter bound involves a constant, depending at most on ggg, which is only known to be effective for hyperelliptic curves XXX over KKK. In addition, we note that [, Theorem 1.2] and [, Theorem 3.2] both depend inter alia on the above mentioned explicit height comparisons of Rémond in [], and such height comparisons are not used in our proof of the displayed inequality.

We point out that our method using the Belyi degree gives that Theorem 3.1, Proposition 3.4 (i) and inequality (5.3) hold more generally for any curve YYY over KKK which admits a finite étale morphism to some X∈𝒞X𝒞X\in\mathcal{C}. Indeed on using that YYY is an étale cover of XXX we deduce from Hurwitz that degB⁢(Y)subscriptdegBY\textnormal{deg}_{B}(Y) is explicitly bounded in terms of degB⁢(X)subscriptdegBX\textnormal{deg}_{B}(X) and the genus of YYY, and then the above arguments prove the generalization. Here we used in addition [, Corollary 4.10] which assures that if vvv is an arbitrary finite place of KKK and XXX has bad reduction at vvv, then YYY has bad reduction at vvv.

Finally, we mention that the method, used in our paper, gives an affine plane model f⁢(z1,z2)=0fsubscriptz1subscriptz20f(z_{1},z_{2})=0 of XK¯subscriptXnormal-¯KX_{\bar{K}} such that if ai∈K¯subscriptainormal-¯Ka_{i}\in\bar{K} is a coefficient of fff, then h⁢(ai)≤νd⁢ν⁢(DK⁢NS)ν.hsubscriptaisuperscriptνdνsuperscriptsubscriptDKsubscriptNSνh(a_{i})\leq\nu^{d\nu}(D_{K}N_{S})^{\nu}.

6 Hyperelliptic curves

In this section we prove Theorem 3.2. We also show two lemmas which provide explicit results for certain (Arakelov) invariants of hyperelliptic curves. Throughout this section we denote by XXX a hyperelliptic curve over a number field KKK of genus g≥2g2g\geq 2.

As before, we denote by XσsubscriptXσX_{\sigma} the compact connected Riemann surface corresponding to the base change of XXX to ℂℂ\mathbb{C} with respect to an embedding σ:K↪ℂnormal-:σnormal-↪Kℂ\sigma:K\hookrightarrow\mathbb{C}. Let T⁢(Xσ)TsubscriptXσT(X_{\sigma}) be the invariant of de Jong. It is the norm of a canonical isomorphism between certain line bundles on XσsubscriptXσX_{\sigma} and we refer to [, Definition 4.2] for a precise definition of T⁢(Xσ)TsubscriptXσT(X_{\sigma}).

Lemma 6.1.

It holds -36⁢g3≤log⁡T⁢(Xσ)36superscriptg3TsubscriptXσ-36g^{3}\leq\log T(X_{\sigma}).

To prove this lemma we use de Jong’s formula [, Theorem 4.7]. It expresses T⁢(Xσ)TsubscriptXσT(X_{\sigma}) in terms of a certain hyperelliptic discriminant modular form, which we then estimate on using the explicit inequality in [, Lemma 5.4].

Proof of Lemma 6.1.

We begin to state the formula for T⁢(Xσ)TsubscriptXσT(X_{\sigma}) in [, Theorem 4.7]. Let ℌgsubscriptℌg\mathfrak{H}_{g} be the Siegel upper half plane of complex symmetric g×gggg\times g matrices with positive definite imaginary part. We denote by Δgsubscriptnormal-Δg\Delta_{g} the hyperelliptic discriminant modular form on ℌgsubscriptℌg\mathfrak{H}_{g}, defined in [, Section 5]. Since XXX is hyperelliptic, there exists a finite morphism φ:Xσ→ℙℂ1normal-:φnormal-→subscriptXσsuperscriptsubscriptℙℂ1\varphi:X_{\sigma}\to\mathbb{P}_{\mathbb{C}}^{1} of degree two. Write H1⁢(Xσ,ℤ)subscriptH1subscriptXσℤH_{1}(X_{\sigma},{\mathbb{Z}}) for the first homology group of XσsubscriptXσX_{\sigma} with coefficients in ℤℤ{\mathbb{Z}}. As in Mumford [, Chapter IIIa], we obtain a canonical symplectic basis of H1⁢(Xσ,ℤ)subscriptH1subscriptXσℤH_{1}(X_{\sigma},{\mathbb{Z}}) with respect to a fixed ordering of the 2⁢g+22g22g+2 branch points of φφ\varphi. Then [, Theorem 4.7] delivers a basis of the global sections of the sheaf of differentials on XσsubscriptXσX_{\sigma} which has the following property: Integration of this basis over the canonical symplectic basis of H1⁢(Xσ,ℤ)subscriptH1subscriptXσℤH_{1}(X_{\sigma},{\mathbb{Z}}) gives a period matrix τσ∈ℌgsubscriptτσsubscriptℌg\tau_{\sigma}\in\mathfrak{H}_{g} that satisfies

T⁢(Xσ)=(2⁢π)-2⁢g⁢|Δg⁢(τσ)⁢det⁢(im⁢(τσ))2⁢a|-(3⁢g-1)/(8⁢b⁢g),TsubscriptXσsuperscript2π2gsuperscriptsubscriptnormal-Δgsubscriptτσdetsuperscriptimsubscriptτσ2a3g18bgT(X_{\sigma})=(2\pi)^{-2g}\left|\Delta_{g}(\tau_{\sigma})\textnormal{det}(% \textnormal{im}(\tau_{\sigma}))^{2a}\right|^{-(3g-1)/(8bg)},

where a=(2⁢g+1g+1)abinomial2g1g1a=\binom{2g+1}{g+1} and b=(2⁢gg+1)bbinomial2gg1b=\binom{2g}{g+1}. Furthermore, [, Lemma 5.4] gives an effective constant k1subscriptk1k_{1}, depending only on ggg, such that |Δg⁢(τσ)⁢det⁢(im⁢(τσ))2⁢a|≤k1.subscriptnormal-Δgsubscriptτσdetsuperscriptimsubscriptτσ2asubscriptk1\left|\Delta_{g}(\tau_{\sigma})\textnormal{det}(\textnormal{im}(\tau_{\sigma})% )^{2a}\right|\leq k_{1}. The effective constant k1subscriptk1k_{1} is explicitly computed in [, (15)], and then the displayed formula for T⁢(Xσ)TsubscriptXσT(X_{\sigma}) leads to an inequality as stated in Lemma 6.1. ∎

Let hF⁢(J)subscripthFJh_{F}(J) be the absolute stable Faltings height of the Jacobian JJJ of XXX and let hN⁢TsubscripthNTh_{NT} be the Néron-Tate height which is defined in (2.2).

Lemma 6.2.

If 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} denotes the set of Weierstrass points of XXX, then

∑x∈𝒲hN⁢T⁢(x)≤(3⁢g-1)⁢(8⁢g+4)⁢hF⁢(J)+293⁢g5.subscriptx𝒲subscripthNTx3g18g4subscripthFJ293superscriptg5\sum_{x\in\mathcal{W}}h_{NT}(x)\leq(3g-1)(8g+4)h_{F}(J)+293g^{5}.

To prove Lemma 6.2 we use de Jong’s formula [, Theorem 4.3]. This formula involves inter alia hF⁢(J)subscripthFJh_{F}(J) and ∑x∈𝒲hN⁢T⁢(x)subscriptx𝒲subscripthNTx\sum_{x\in\mathcal{W}}h_{NT}(x), and an analytic term, related to T⁢(Xσ)TsubscriptXσT(X_{\sigma}), which we control by Lemma 6.1.

Proof of Lemma 6.2.

To state the formula in [, Theorem 4.3] we introduce quantities A1,A2subscriptA1subscriptA2A_{1},A_{2} and A3subscriptA3A_{3}. Let LLL be a finite extension of KKK such that XLsubscriptXLX_{L} has semi-stable reduction over the spectrum BBB of the ring of integers of LLL and such that all Weierstrass points of XXX are in X⁢(L)XLX(L). We define

A1=-4⁢g⁢(2⁢g-1)⁢(g+1)⁢log⁡(2⁢π)+8⁢g2[L:ℚ]⁢∑log⁡T⁢(Xσ)subscriptA14g2g1g12π8superscriptg2normal-:LℚTsubscriptXσA_{1}=-4g(2g-1)(g+1)\log(2\pi)+\frac{8g^{2}}{[L:{\mathbb{Q}}]}\sum\log T(X_{% \sigma})

with the sum taken over all embeddings σ:L↪ℂ.normal-:σnormal-↪Lℂ\sigma:L\hookrightarrow\mathbb{C}. Let 𝒳→Bnormal-→𝒳B\mathcal{X}\to B, (⋅,⋅)fragmentsnormal-(normal-⋅normal-,normal-⋅normal-)(\cdot,\cdot) and ωω\omega be as in (2.1). We denote by EEE the residual divisor on 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} defined in [, p.286]. Let Δ⁢(X)normal-ΔX\Delta(X) be the stable discriminant of XXX defined in (4.4). We take

A2=(2⁢g-1)⁢(g+1)⁢Δ⁢(X)+4[L:ℚ]⁢(E,ω).subscriptA22g1g1normal-ΔX4normal-:LℚEωA_{2}=(2g-1)(g+1)\Delta(X)+\frac{4}{[L:{\mathbb{Q}}]}(E,\omega).

For any section x∈𝒳⁢(B)x𝒳Bx\in\mathcal{X}(B) of 𝒳→Bnormal-→𝒳B\mathcal{X}\to B, let Φxsubscriptnormal-Φx\Phi_{x} be the (unique) vertical ℚℚ{\mathbb{Q}}-Cartier divisor on 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} such that the supports of Φxsubscriptnormal-Φx\Phi_{x} and x⁢(B)xBx(B) are disjoint and any irreducible component Γnormal-Γ\Gamma of any fiber of 𝒳→Bnormal-→𝒳B\mathcal{X}\to B satisfies ((2⁢g-2)⁢x-ω+Φx,Γ)=02g2xωsubscriptnormal-Φxnormal-Γ0((2g-2)x-\omega+\Phi_{x},\Gamma)=0. We write

A3=1[L:ℚ]g(g-1)⁢∑x∈𝒲-(Φx,Φx)⁢nxsubscriptA31fragmentsfragmentsnormal-[Lnormal-:Qnormal-]gfragmentsnormal-(g1normal-)subscriptx𝒲subscriptnormal-Φxsubscriptnormal-ΦxsubscriptnxA_{3}=\frac{1}{[L:{\mathbb{Q}}]g(g-1)}\sum_{x\in\mathcal{W}}-(\Phi_{x},\Phi_{x% })n_{x}

with nxsubscriptnxn_{x} the multiplicity of xxx in the Weierstrass divisor WWW on 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, where WWW is defined in [, p.286]. Then [, Theorem 4.3] gives

(3⁢g-1)⁢(8⁢g+4)⁢hF⁢(J)=A1+A2+A3+2g⁢(g-1)⁢∑x∈𝒲hN⁢T⁢(x)⁢nx.3g18g4subscripthFJsubscriptA1subscriptA2subscriptA32gg1subscriptx𝒲subscripthNTxsubscriptnx(3g-1)(8g+4)h_{F}(J)=A_{1}+A_{2}+A_{3}+\frac{2}{g(g-1)}\sum_{x\in\mathcal{W}}h% _{NT}(x)n_{x}.

We now estimate the quantities A1,A2subscriptA1subscriptA2A_{1},A_{2} and A3subscriptA3A_{3} from below. To deal with A1subscriptA1A_{1} we use Lemma 6.1. It gives -293⁢g5≤A1.293superscriptg5subscriptA1-293g^{5}\leq A_{1}. The divisor EEE on 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} is vertical and effective, and our minimal 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} does not contain any exceptional curves. This implies that (E,ω)≥0Eω0(E,\omega)\geq 0. Then Δ⁢(X)≥0normal-ΔX0\Delta(X)\geq 0 and -(ϕx,ϕx)≥0subscriptϕxsubscriptϕx0-(\phi_{x},\phi_{x})\geq 0 show that A2subscriptA2A_{2} and A3subscriptA3A_{3} are both non-negative. Furthermore, [, Lemma 3.2] gives nx=g⁢(g-1)/2subscriptnxgg12n_{x}=g(g-1)/2. Thus the above displayed formula and the lower bounds for A1,A2subscriptA1subscriptA2A_{1},A_{2} and A3subscriptA3A_{3} imply an inequality as claimed. ∎

On using the inequality given in Lemma 6.2 we now prove Theorem 3.2 and Proposition 3.4 (ii) simultaneously.

Proof of Theorem 3.2 and Proposition 3.4 (ii).

Since XXX is a hyperelliptic curve over KKK, there exists a finite morphism X→ℙK1normal-→Xsubscriptsuperscriptℙ1KX\to\mathbb{P}^{1}_{K} which is geometrically a cyclic cover of prime degree two. Then, on combining Lemma 6.2, Lemma 5.2 and inequality (5.2), we deduce Theorem 3.2 and Proposition 3.4 (ii). ∎

7 Genus two curves

In this section we prove Theorem 3.3 and Proposition 3.4 (iii).

Let cδ⁢(2)subscriptcδ2c_{\delta}(2) be the minimum of Faltings’ delta invariant on M2⁢(ℂ)subscriptM2ℂM_{2}({\mathbb{C}}), see (4.3). The following lemma was established in [, Proposition 5.1 (v)].

Lemma 7.1.

It holds -186≤cδ⁢(2)186subscriptcδ2-186\leq c_{\delta}(2).

We now combine Lemma 7.1 with the arguments used in the proof of Proposition 5.3 to prove Theorem 3.3 and Proposition 3.4 (iii).

Proof of Theorem 3.3 and Proposition 3.4 (iii).

Let XXX be a genus two curve over a number field KKK. It is a hyperelliptic curve over KKK by [, Proposition 7.4.9]. Thus there exists a finite morphism X→ℙK1normal-→Xsubscriptsuperscriptℙ1KX\to\mathbb{P}^{1}_{K} which is geometrically a cyclic cover of prime degree two. As before, we denote by hhh and hN⁢TsubscripthNTh_{NT} the stable Arakelov height and the Néron-Tate height respectively, defined in (2.1) and (2.2). Then Lemma 4.3, Lemma 4.4, inequality (5.2) and Lemma 7.1 give infinitely many x∈X⁢(K¯)xXnormal-¯Kx\in X(\bar{K}) that satisfy

14⁢hN⁢T⁢(x)≤h⁢(x)≤6⁢u⁢(2)⁢μX+10114subscripthNTxhx6u2subscriptμX101\frac{1}{4}h_{NT}(x)\leq h(x)\leq 6u(2)\mu_{X}+101

for μXsubscriptμX\mu_{X} as in (5.1) and u⁢(2)u2u(2) as in Proposition 3.4. Thus the upper bounds for μXsubscriptμX\mu_{X} in Lemma 5.2 (i) and Lemma 5.2 (ii) imply Theorem 3.3 and Proposition 3.4 (iii) respectively. ∎
